channel.title: LSE Government Department HotSeat
channel.description: 'The HotSeat' is the LSE Department of Government's video and podcast series which asks leading LSE experts important questions on the key issues in politics and government. To find out more visit - http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/government/hotseat/
channel.itunes:summary: 'The HotSeat' is the LSE Department of Government's video and podcast series which asks leading LSE experts important questions on the key issues in politics and government. To find out more visit - http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/government/hotseat/
channel.copyright: Copyright © Terms of use apply see https://www.lse.ac.uk/termsOfUse/
channel.itunes:author: London School of Economics and Political Science

item.title: Tony Travers discusses the 2018 Local Elections
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | What did the 2018 Local Elections tell us about the current landscape of British Politics? Professor Tony Travers gives us his analysis.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | What did the 2018 Local Elections tell us about the current landscape of British Politics? Professor Tony Travers gives us his analysis.

item.title: Tony Travers on Party Conference Season 2017
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | What's the point of party conferences? Professor Tony Travers gives us his analysis of the 2017 party conference season. Watch the latest episodes of #LSEHotSeat on GovBlog - http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/government/hotseat
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | What's the point of party conferences? Professor Tony Travers gives us his analysis of the 2017 party conference season. Watch the latest episodes of #LSEHotSeat on GovBlog - http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/government/hotseat

item.title: Tony Travers on the results of the 2017 UK General Election
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | We ask Professor Tony Travers how we ended up with a hung Parliament, the implications for the Conservatives and Labour, what it means for Brexit and how long it could be before the next General Election. Watch the latest episodes of #LSEHotSeat on GovBlog - http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/government/hotseat
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | We ask Professor Tony Travers how we ended up with a hung Parliament, the implications for the Conservatives and Labour, what it means for Brexit and how long it could be before the next General Election. Watch the latest episodes of #LSEHotSeat on GovBlog - http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/government/hotseat

item.title: Thomas Leeper on Trump’s Inauguration & the Start of His Presidency
item.itunes:author: Thomas Leeper
item.description: Contributor(s): Thomas Leeper | Thomas Leeper discusses Donald Trump's inauguration and what it tells us about the policy and approach we can expect from his presidency.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Thomas Leeper | Thomas Leeper discusses Donald Trump's inauguration and what it tells us about the policy and approach we can expect from his presidency.

item.title: Tony Travers on 2016, An Eventful Year In Politics
item.itunes:author: Tony Travers and Emma Rees
item.description: Contributor(s): Tony Travers and Emma Rees | Professor Tony Travers discusses the key political events of 2016, an unprecedented year in politics which saw the UK vote for Brexit and Donald Trump elected US President.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Tony Travers and Emma Rees | Professor Tony Travers discusses the key political events of 2016, an unprecedented year in politics which saw the UK vote for Brexit and Donald Trump elected US President.

item.title: Alexandra Cirone on Post-Truth Politics
item.itunes:author: Alexandra Cirone
item.description: Contributor(s): Alexandra Cirone | What is 'Post-Truth'? Alexandra Cirone discusses the latest political buzzword and what it really means for politics in 2016 and beyond.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Alexandra Cirone | What is 'Post-Truth'? Alexandra Cirone discusses the latest political buzzword and what it really means for politics in 2016 and beyond.

item.title: Brian Klaas on the 2016 US Presidential Election and Implications of a Trump Presidency
item.itunes:author: Brian Klaas
item.description: Contributor(s): Brian Klaas | As the world continues to digest the outcome of the 2016 US Presidential Election, Brian Klaas discusses the result and what we might expect from a Donald Trump Presidency.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Brian Klaas | As the world continues to digest the outcome of the 2016 US Presidential Election, Brian Klaas discusses the result and what we might expect from a Donald Trump Presidency.

item.title: Tony Travers on the Oldham By-election
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | The Oldham West and Royton by-election was the first electoral test of Jeremy Corbyn's Labour leadership, which came under even further scrutiny in the wake of events surrounding the parliamentary vote on Syria. Professor Tony Travers discusses Jim McMahon's victory for Labour, its implications for the party and its leader, and what the result means for UKIP.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | The Oldham West and Royton by-election was the first electoral test of Jeremy Corbyn's Labour leadership, which came under even further scrutiny in the wake of events surrounding the parliamentary vote on Syria. Professor Tony Travers discusses Jim McMahon's victory for Labour, its implications for the party and its leader, and what the result means for UKIP.

item.title: Kate Alexander Shaw on the Autumn Statement 2015
item.itunes:author: Kate Alexander Shaw
item.description: Contributor(s): Kate Alexander Shaw | Since presenting his Budget in July George, Osborne has faced significant challenges to some of his spending policies, particularly the widespread opposition to his plans to cut tax credits. Kate Alexander Shaw gives her verdict on the latest proposals announced in his Autumn Statement and their political and practical implications.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Kate Alexander Shaw | Since presenting his Budget in July George, Osborne has faced significant challenges to some of his spending policies, particularly the widespread opposition to his plans to cut tax credits. Kate Alexander Shaw gives her verdict on the latest proposals announced in his Autumn Statement and their political and practical implications.

item.title: Jonathan Hopkin on Catalonia
item.itunes:author: Dr Jonathan Hopkin, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Dr Jonathan Hopkin, Martin Rogers | On the 27 September voters went to the polls in the 2015 Catalonian Parliamentary Election. We sat down with Dr Jonathan Hopkin to discuss the results and the implications for those in the region seeking independence from Spain.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Dr Jonathan Hopkin, Martin Rogers | On the 27 September voters went to the polls in the 2015 Catalonian Parliamentary Election. We sat down with Dr Jonathan Hopkin to discuss the results and the implications for those in the region seeking independence from Spain.

item.title: Tony Travers on the UK party conference season and the state of the race to be Mayor of London
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | Tony Travers discusses UK party conference season and the state of the race to be Mayor of London. He also previews the May 2016 London Mayoral election.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | Tony Travers discusses UK party conference season and the state of the race to be Mayor of London. He also previews the May 2016 London Mayoral election.

item.title: Martin Lodge on the VW emissions 'scandal'
item.itunes:author: Professor Martin Lodge, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Martin Lodge, Martin Rogers | In September VW admitted to using software which enabled some of their vehicles to cheat US emissions tests. We sat down with Professor Martin Lodge to discuss the situation and its implications in the US, Europe and beyond.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Martin Lodge, Martin Rogers | In September VW admitted to using software which enabled some of their vehicles to cheat US emissions tests. We sat down with Professor Martin Lodge to discuss the situation and its implications in the US, Europe and beyond.

item.title: Simon Hix on the election of Jeremy Corbyn as the new leader of the Labour Party
item.itunes:author: Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers | Simon Hix discusses the election of Jeremy Corbyn as the new leader of the Labour Party and the implications of this for British Politics.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers | Simon Hix discusses the election of Jeremy Corbyn as the new leader of the Labour Party and the implications of this for British Politics.

item.title: Tony Travers on the 2016 London Mayoral Election
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | On 5 May 2016 the people of London will go to the polls to elect the city’s new Mayor. We sat down with Professor Tony Travers to discuss the potential candidates and the key issues which could decide how Londoners vote.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | On 5 May 2016 the people of London will go to the polls to elect the city’s new Mayor. We sat down with Professor Tony Travers to discuss the potential candidates and the key issues which could decide how Londoners vote.

item.title: Laura Robbins-Wright on the migration situation in Calais
item.itunes:author: Laura Robbins-Wright, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Laura Robbins-Wright, Martin Rogers | The plight of migrants in Calais and their attempts to cross into the UK have received increasing media coverage over the summer. Laura Robbins-Wright discusses the current situation and possible options for resolving it.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Laura Robbins-Wright, Martin Rogers | The plight of migrants in Calais and their attempts to cross into the UK have received increasing media coverage over the summer. Laura Robbins-Wright discusses the current situation and possible options for resolving it.

item.title: Tony Travers on the Labour leadership contest
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | With the Labour leadership contest becoming perhaps the key British political story of the summer, we sat down with Professor Tony Travers to discuss the candidates, the contest so far and its implications for the future of the party and the UK’s overall political landscape.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | With the Labour leadership contest becoming perhaps the key British political story of the summer, we sat down with Professor Tony Travers to discuss the candidates, the contest so far and its implications for the future of the party and the UK’s overall political landscape.

item.title: Charlie Beckett on the future of the BBC
item.itunes:author: Professor Charlie Beckett, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Charlie Beckett, Martin Rogers | Following the announcement of a consultation on the BBC’s future, we sat down with Professor Charlie Beckett to discuss what the implications could be both for the BBC itself and the overall media landscape.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Charlie Beckett, Martin Rogers | Following the announcement of a consultation on the BBC’s future, we sat down with Professor Charlie Beckett to discuss what the implications could be both for the BBC itself and the overall media landscape.

item.title: Simon Hix on the crisis in Greece
item.itunes:author: Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers | On the Friday following the Greek people’s decisive referendum no vote, we sat down with Professor Simon Hix to discuss the implications of the rapidly evolving crisis for Greece and its European neighbours.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers | On the Friday following the Greek people’s decisive referendum no vote, we sat down with Professor Simon Hix to discuss the implications of the rapidly evolving crisis for Greece and its European neighbours.

item.title: Kate Alexander Shaw on Budget 2015
item.itunes:author: Kate Alexander Shaw, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Kate Alexander Shaw, Martin Rogers | In the wake of the first majority Conservative budget since the mid 90s, Kate Alexander Shaw discusses the implications of the policies outlined by George Osborne.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Kate Alexander Shaw, Martin Rogers | In the wake of the first majority Conservative budget since the mid 90s, Kate Alexander Shaw discusses the implications of the policies outlined by George Osborne.

item.title: Martin Lodge on FIFA
item.itunes:author: Professor Martin Lodge, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Martin Lodge, Martin Rogers | Professor Martin Lodge discusses allegations of widespread corruption at FIFA, football’s world governing body, following the launch of a US led investigation.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Martin Lodge, Martin Rogers | Professor Martin Lodge discusses allegations of widespread corruption at FIFA, football’s world governing body, following the launch of a US led investigation.

item.title: Simon Hix on the Queen's Speech
item.itunes:author: Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers | Following the first Queen’s Speech under a Conservative majority since 1996, Professor Simon Hix discusses the key bills proposed by the government.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Simon Hix, Martin Rogers | Following the first Queen’s Speech under a Conservative majority since 1996, Professor Simon Hix discusses the key bills proposed by the government.

item.title: Tony Travers on the aftermath of the 2015 General Election
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | As the dust settles following one of the most intriguing General Elections in recent history, Professor Tony Travers discusses what the outcome means for parties across the political spectrum.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | As the dust settles following one of the most intriguing General Elections in recent history, Professor Tony Travers discusses what the outcome means for parties across the political spectrum.

item.title: Tony Travers on the 2015 General Election result
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | On the morning after the 2015 General Election, as the UK attempts to make sense of a result which took many commentators by surprise, Professor Tony Travers gives his initial reaction. Why did the exit poll differ so much from the polling in the run up to the election and what does the result mean for both the winners and the losers?
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers, Martin Rogers | On the morning after the 2015 General Election, as the UK attempts to make sense of a result which took many commentators by surprise, Professor Tony Travers gives his initial reaction. Why did the exit poll differ so much from the polling in the run up to the election and what does the result mean for both the winners and the losers?

item.title: Tony Travers on the General Election campaign so far
item.itunes:author: Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | As the general election approaches, Professor Tony Travers discusses the campaign so far. Which campaign strategies have been effective and what are the key issues the parties have focussed on?
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Tony Travers | As the general election approaches, Professor Tony Travers discusses the campaign so far. Which campaign strategies have been effective and what are the key issues the parties have focussed on?

item.title: Vernon Bogdanor on the General Election 2015
item.itunes:author: Professor Vernon Bogdanor, Professor Tony Travers
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Vernon Bogdanor, Professor Tony Travers | Professor Vernon Bogdanor discusses the General Election 2015 with Professor Tony Travers. What can historic and recent elections tell us about this year’s contest, the rise of multi-party politics and the potential outcomes in the event of a hung parliament on 7 May? Vernon Bogdanor is Research Professor at the Institute for Contemporary British History at King's College London and Professor of Politics at the New College of the Humanities.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Vernon Bogdanor, Professor Tony Travers | Professor Vernon Bogdanor discusses the General Election 2015 with Professor Tony Travers. What can historic and recent elections tell us about this year’s contest, the rise of multi-party politics and the potential outcomes in the event of a hung parliament on 7 May? Vernon Bogdanor is Research Professor at the Institute for Contemporary British History at King's College London and Professor of Politics at the New College of the Humanities.

item.title: Political representation
item.itunes:author: Professor Anne Phillips
item.description: Contributor(s): Professor Anne Phillips | Political representation in a democracy doesn't necessarily reflect the variety of people within a society. Most noticeably, there is a much lower percentage of women acting as representatives than there is in the wider population. Does this matter? Anne Phillips believes it does.
item.itunes:summary: Contributor(s): Professor Anne Phillips | Political representation in a democracy doesn't necessarily reflect the variety of people within a society.
